stem: A 55-year-old client is receiving Morphine via a Patient-Controlled Analgesia (PCA) pump for post-operative pain. Based on the documentation in the PCA Monitoring & Capnography flowsheet, which finding is the earliest indicator of impending respiratory failure?

tabs.title: PCA Settings
tabs.content:
Drug: Morphine 1mg/mL.
Basal Rate: 1 mg/hr.
Demand Dose: 1 mg.
Lockout: 10 minutes.

options.text: The rise in End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2) from 38 to 54 mmHg
The decrease in respiratory rate to 8 breaths per minute
The drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 91%
The POSS sedation score of 3 at 1800

rationale.correct: In opioid monitoring, **Sedation (a4)** always precedes respiratory depression. A POSS (Pasero Opioid-Induced Sedation Scale) score of 3 (falls asleep during conversation) is the earliest clinical indicator that the client is over-sedated and at high risk for subsequent respiratory failure. While EtCO2 (a1) is a very early *technological* indicator (hypoventilation causes CO2 to rise before O2 drops), the sedation level at 1800 was the first clinical turning point where intervention (holding the dose) should have occurred.
clinicalPearls: End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2) is more sensitive than Pulse Oximetry (SpO2) for detecting early opioid-induced respiratory depression (OIRD).
A POSS score of 3 means 'Unacceptable' sedation; the nurse must monitor closely and likely reduce the opioid dose.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing SpO2 or Respirations as the 'earliest' indicator.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Oxygen levels (SpO2) are LATE indicators because oxygen remains in the blood even after a person stops breathing well. Sedation is always the FIRST sign of trouble.

mnemonic.title: S-C-R-O
mnemonic.expansion: S-Sleepy (Sedation). C-CO2 up. R-Respirations down. O-Oxygen down. (The order of failure).
